Guide to the Stanford Student Letters and Memoirs Collection SC0103

did.unittitle: Stanford student letters and memoirs collection

origination.label: creator

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Stanford Student Letters and Memoirs Collection (SC0103). Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The first series of this collection contains letters, reminiscences, diaries and account books, autobiographies, and other items from a number of Stanford University students. Most of the letters are written home to family members; typical subjects include academic affairs, social life on campus and off, fraternity and sorority affairs, and athletics. Other subjects include events at the Stanford home and the settlement of Leland Stanford's estate.
The second series consists of email and text messages sent home from students.

accessrestrict.head: Access to Collection
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: All requests to reproduce, publish, quote from, or otherwise use collection materials must be submitted in writing to the Head of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, California 94305-6064. Consent is given on behalf of Special Collections as the owner of the physical items and is not intended to include or imply permission from the copyright owner. Such permission must be obtained from the copyright owner, heir(s) or assigns. See: http://library.stanford.edu/depts/spc/pubserv/permissions.html.
Restrictions also apply to digital representations of the original materials. Use of digital files is restricted to research and educational purposes.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [identification of item], Stanford Student Letters and Memoirs Collection (SC0103). Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in two series. Series 1: letters, series 2: emails and text messages.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The materials have been digitized and are available online: https://searchworks.stanford.edu/view/4085089.

controlaccess.corpname: Stanford University. Libraries. Department of Special Collections and University Archives

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of William Hyde Irwin, 1973

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters, 1894 to 1895, from Harriet Sophia (Hallie) Hyde, a freshman at Stanford, to her mother, Mrs. William Birelie Hyde, including one letter mentioning the campus reaction to news of the decision on the settlement of Leland Stanford's estate.

did.unittitle: Correspondence fom Harriet (Hallie) Hyde to her mother

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Purchased from Edward Morrill and Son, 1973

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This bound typescript entitled "A Semester at Stanford" includes contemporary photographs and a note from Blake to Mrs. A. G. Everett, describing the manuscript. Subjects include hazing, the Frosh-Soph Tie-Up, the Plug Ugly fights, excursions off campus, pajama parades, and the football game between Stanford and Berkeley.

did.unittitle: "A semester at Stanford," [1907], bound together with contemporary photographs
Blake to Mrs. A. G. Everett; and unbound photographs

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Nancy Bohlander, 1976

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of four letters from J. T. Colliver to his son John Adams Colliver (A.B. 1896) at Stanford, along with a handwritten fight song and miscellaneous receipts.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Harold Hjelm, November 1975

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ernest Klette attended Stanford University from 1902 to 1905; this series consists of two letters and one postcard from Klette to his sister Birdie discussing a reception for new students at Mrs. Stanford's house, the choir, and his schoolwork.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: April 2002: These letters have been removed and processed with additional letters as Osborne Family Papers (SC0636)

did.unittitle: James D. Taggart and Katherine Taggart Spinks Papers

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Mr. Taggart Spinks, 1975

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous receipts, cancelled checks, and student documents of James Dean Taggart, class of 1909, and Katherine Taggart Spinks, class of 1914.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Ruth G. Allen, 1976

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains approximately 125 letters from Frederic Jewell Perry, class of 1900, to his mother, discussing student life on campus, especially the affairs of the Kappa Sigma fraternity.

did.unittitle: Schulte, William Henry (A.B. May 1895) to his sister Nannie, discussing professors and literary activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection of papers from Tex Bollman Allen, class of 1933, includes his letters to his family discussing his friends, sports, classes, and potential fraternity life; one letter from Benjamin A. Clark, 3 Dec. 1929; and miscellaneous receipts and notes.

did.unittitle: Receipts, notes, and letter from B. A. Clark
Letter to Kenneth Smith, Stanford Alumni Association, regarding the Stanford Crew Team of 1912 to 1918
Letter to Bessie Anderson regarding the December 1892 Big Game
Letter to Dave, (possibly David Lamson), relating to Nolan's blossoming stage career

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These letters were written by Rose Payne, A.B. 1898, and Theodora Payne, A.B. 1900, to "Nannie" in San Jose, possibly an aunt. They describe their student life at Stanford including classes and lectures, athletics, sorority matters, and social events with other students and faculty. There is also some mention of Jane Stanford and the govenment suit against the estate of Leland Stanford.

did.unittitle: Freshman-Sophomore reception; death of Mrs. Pease.
Production of "Tribly;" Bonfire; celebration on account of decision for suit processions.
Big Game; Thanksgiving Day at Stanford.
Big Game results; Thanksgiving vacation and dance; course descriptions.
Prof. Clarke description; Fort Stoniax bank failure.
Celebrations over suit decision; Founder's Day; University committees.
Chancy M. Deperd speech with Cornelius Vanderbilt.
Exams and commencement; Roble reception for the faculty.
French Revolution lectures; English 11; Stanford Day.
McKinley's election; Dr. Jordan's party; Thanksgiving Dance.
Visit with Mrs. Stanford; description of her home and dress and personality.
Card party at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Angell with Dr. and Mrs. Fairclough.
Winning of Big Game; pride in the University; Thanksgiving.
Prof. Hudson's course re Mathew Arnold.
Suspension of 7 Roble girls and Mrs. Clement (Roble director) due to drinking incident; mentions Mrs. Baker as replacement.
Dr. Jordan's 46th birthday party; visit with Prof. Anderson and his family.
Jordan's poem published in Sequoia; dance with Sigma Rho Eta.
Description of Cotilion; comments on fraternity question at Stanford.
Informal party at the home of Prof. Allardice with Profs. Campbell, Kellogg, Fairclough and Hodges; proposed improvment of Roble dining room.
New Orleans French Grand Opera Co. at the California and description of Shakespeare exam.
Welsh rarebit party given by Mr. Nash in Encina; comments on the party, Mr. Nash.
Jordan's reception for the seniors; mentions Mrs. Stanford.
Transcripts of Allabach's letters to family, primarily her mother,

did.unittitle: Typescript memoirs of his student life stressing influence of particular professors

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes letters by Myron Burr, class of 1907, written while a student, describing Jane Stanford's funeral and the 1906 earthquake; and correspondence pertaining to reunions of the Class of 1907, 1932-1940.

did.unittitle: Diary describing life in early Palo Alto, impressions of Jane Stanford, and experiences in the 1906 earthquake at Stanford.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Samuel R. Durand, 1981 and 1982

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Samuel B. Durand earned his Civil Engineering degree in May 1894; these letters to his brother discuss campus buildings, Benjamin Harrison's lecture series, Junior Day activities, Berkeley Day activities, student tennis matches, and his negative impression of David Starr Jordan, the University President.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of P. Meissner, 1979

did.unittitle: Diary of a journey from Ohio to California; and cash accounts at Stanford University

Letters of recommendation from David Starr Jordan, Orrin Leslie Elliott, and J. E. McDowell; and letter from Evans-Wentz to Ray Lyman Wilbur regarding an educational trust fund, endowing a professorship at Stanford.
List of rules for student conduct,

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Burnham P. Beckwith, January 1983

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These papers of Beckwith, class of 1926, include letters, a class paper, and a chapter from his autobiography. Subjects in the letters include his academic work, being on the staff of the student newspaper, excursions to San Francisco, his activities on the debating team, athletic and social events, and lectures attended, with occassional discussion of ideas such as socialism and religion.

did.unittitle: Letters home to his parents; paper on religion; and two photographs : Beckwith with friends and Branner Hall
"My four years at Stanford, 1922-1926." Chapter VI, Autobiography of Burnham Putnam Beckwith,

Two letters from Ellen F. Thompson; three letters from Dora Murdy

custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Ralph Weinrichter, 1992

did.unittitle: Letter to Andrew Durham, describing what she likes about Stanford, the fraternities, the surrounding countryside, and the students.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Purchased from Howard Hein, 1985

did.unittitle: Two letters to his family describing his race at a track event, writing for the student newspaper, fraternity life and affairs, and meetings with Charles Lathrop, business manager for the University, and John C. Branner, President of the University.

custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Dorothy Cone Moore, 1985

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Mrs. Dorothy Cone Moore, 1985

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Michitaro Sindo, a Japanese student at Stanford from 1900 to 1906, worked with David S. Jordan on ichthyological studies and the Commission to study Hawaiian fishes. While at Stanford he was tutored by Elizabeth Cone, who earned her A.B. in English in 1901 and was a graduate student and assistant in the English Department, 1906-1908.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These letters to Cone discuss his ichthyological work in Hawaii with Dr. Jordan, 1901, and in Samoa with Jordan and Dr. Kellogg, 1902; his description of Samoa and its people, including his visit to Robert Louis Stevenson's residence and grave; his assessment of Japanese home and social life (in reaction to an article in Outlook); and his academic work at Stanford, 1901.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Peter and Carl Knecht, 1985

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Knecht earned his B.A. in geology at Stanford in 1899 and his M.A. in 1900. After a year in California as a geologist, Knecht worked for several mining companies in South Africa. He died in Johannesburg on July 12, 1925.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These letters were written to his family in Los Angeles from September 1895 to May 1896 and discuss his classes, exams, fees and expenses, the celebration on campus after decision in court case on Leland Stanford's estate, excursions to S. F. Bay, and advice from Dr. Branner. Also included is the English entrance exam test he took.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: Gift of Eri Horner Richarson, Jr., 1985

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Richardson attended classes at Stanford between 1905 and 1907. From evidence in the letters, he supported himself in part by rebuilding the Jordans' chimney after the 1906 earthquake.

did.unittitle: Letter from G. A. Clark; sheet on self-support for students; and letter from Jessie Knight Jordan, with endorsement by D. S. Jordan on Richardson's work

custodhist.head: Custodial History note

did.unittitle: Letter to family regarding celebrations on campus after decision in court case on Leland Stanford's estate and an excursions into Santa Cruz mountains in the snow

bioghist.p: Tarbell earned his A.B. in electrical engineering in May 1907.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Email and text message correspondence between Stanford students and their families. Materials submitted to the University Archives electronically as part of the Stanford Alumni Legacy Project initiative. Emails are submitted directly to the Stanford University Archives at yourstanfordlegacy@stanford.edu; text messages are submitted directly to (415) 952-7241. Files consist of email and/or text messages, or screenshots thereof. Contextual explanations and descriptions of messages are sometimes provided by donors. File formats primarily include: .eml, .jpg, .pdf, .docx, .csv, and .htm.
